textblock.words: The ePubChef code will be fully owned by the author and act as a wrapper around the book text. This enables the author to retain full control of his or her work. A valid set of EPUB files can be produced as often as desired during the life of the book from first outline to completed work. The ePubChef can run on Windows, Mac, or Linux. While book generation is automated, there is also the capability for creative formatting of the book and even automated personalization of each copy.

With the ePubChef ugly, poorly formatted electronic publications should become a thing of the past. Authors will not be dependent on technical experts to publish. EBook creation experts can concentrate on adding value through style and formatting without monotonous, error prone copying and pasting.

There are many things you may want to do within your text. ePubChef will do several things automatically. For example, it will change boring straight quotes to smart quotes as in the following paragraph. The tool will create a new paragraph after each blank line in your text. A setting in the recipe will create drop-caps for the first letter of each chapter.
<ul>
• put text in italics
• create a list like this one
She said, “this is a quote.” Then she followed with, “another quotation.”
“What is this quotation about?” she said.
If you prefer single quotes: She said, ‘this is a quote.’ Then she followed with, ‘another quotation.’
‘What is this quotation about?’ she said.
<ul>
• characters such as ampersand are dealt with correctly: &
• There was a double space removed before the word double.
• This line began with a tab which has been removed.
• There's a single quote here which was converted to a smart quote.

This line had leading white-space removed and replaced with a normal paragraph indentation. Three dots have been changed to an ellipses … which looks nicer. This line contains utf-8 character (r squared =20), r²=20. For full control one can enter any HTML. HTML will pass through ePubChef unaltered. For example, an HTML table. Full style control is available by tailoring CSS.
<table border="1">
aaaa1111
bbbb222
cccc8888
Images can be placed in the pages: . Note that if a line ends with an HTML tag the whole line is treated as HTML and so should be wrapped in paragraph tags.
Nested list example (using HTML):
<ol>
• one
• two
<li>
<ul>
• aaa
• bbb
• ccc
• three
Insert a blank line between two paragraphs.
Use the HTML break <br/>.
To show HTML on the page as text, replace the leading less than with “& l t ;” (without the spaces).

An ePubChef “recipe” file is the control file for generation of an eBook. Open /demo_raw/demo_recipe.yaml for an example. Entries in the front and back matter sections can be moved, added to, or removed. If you create a new entry, you must also create a template file with the same name. It is usually best to copy an existing, similar template and alter it.
Entries under sections “parts” and “chapters” can be added or changed. Alter the appropriate change in the template to match.

Generally, eBook readers are most stable and predictable using their own built-in fonts. However, one can attempt to control fonts used. This is done by putting the font library in the ePubChef “/fonts” folder. For best eBook reader compatability use .ttf or .woff files. Open source fonts can be obtained from http://www.google.com/fonts (or other sources) and if necesary converted at http://everythingfonts.com/ttf-to-woff.
Set the /css/epub-stylesheet.css to include the @font-face entries for your font(s). and use it in the css, such as: font-family: ‘Courgette', sans-serif;

The chapter headers of this documen are an example of using a non-standard font. HOWEVER, while the custom font is rendered correctly in some readers, such as Adobe Digital Editions, it is not in others (Calibre and Kindle Paperwhite).
